text: Even bad code is less embarrassing than no code though IMO

elements.text: Even bad code is less embarrassing than no code though IMO

text:
It depends I think - but I tend to agree. My code wasn't allowed to be shared until after graduation - so it's somewhere on some gov't funding server or something. It's embarassing, but I've handed it out to a few people. My last preprint I couldn't share it either due to 'industry' :confused:.

If the field is like comp sci. yea - you better show something hahaha. But if it's less critical like "I made some plots" or "I did something a million people have done in a new context" not a big deal.

elements.text: It depends I think - but I tend to agree. My code wasn't allowed to be shared until after graduation - so it's somewhere on some gov't funding server or something. It's embarassing, but I've handed it out to a few people. My last preprint I couldn't share it either due to 'industry'

.

If the field is like comp sci. yea - you better show something hahaha. But if it's less critical like "I made some plots" or "I did something a million people have done in a new context" not a big deal.

text: My field has a few notorious "code commercializers" though. Paper would get written, and immediately a company unrelated to the author would be selling the new "feature". So people in my field became gunshy. But culture is changing. Its complicated basically because a few people are jerks.
